A good example is that I asked ChatGPT about the process of applying for an electricity connection at the City of Cape Town. It gave some sensible sounding steps - download forms, fill in forms, then submit on website.

Except you can't submit the forms via the web, for *reasons*

If you've been waiting for full-text #search on #Mastodon, please go to #TootFinder and sign in. The more the merrier.
https://www.tootfinder.ch/

Thanks to @buercher for building it.

It's opt-in, not opt-out. It respects Mastodon culture and doesn't index accounts that don't sign in.

That means the index might be small if we don't spread the word.

title: I had ChatGPT write a Decemberists song

last_post.content:
Colin Meloy of the Decemberists asked #ChatGPT to write a song that Colin Meloy of the Decemberists might have written.

Meloy: "For the record, this is a remarkably mediocre song. I wouldn’t say it’s a terrible song, though it really flirts with terribleness… I want to say that ChatGPT lacks intuition. That’s one thing an AI can’t have, intuition.”

Anyway, Meloy has more intuition about what AI can and can’t do than 90% of the internet

https://colinmeloy.substack.com/p/i-had-chatgpt-write-a-decemberists

title: Theory of Mind May Have Spontaneously Emerged in Large Language Models

last_post.content:
A paper on arXiv finds that an emergent ability to solve Theory-of-Mind (ToM) tasks, in ChatGPT (Thanks @kcarruthers). Such emergent behaviour is particularly interesting because it has not been built into the algorithm by design.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02083

I find particularly intriguing (although the authors don't discuss that point) how beliefs change simply with the length of the conversation, even when no new facts are added. The philosopher Paul Grice stated four maxims of communication: quantity, quality, relation, and manner; aspects that allow speakers and listeners to establish contextual information _implicitly_. It is intriguing to think that this need to evaluate implicit context is a necessary condition for natural communication, and that this is the stimulus for ToM emergence.

I'm intrigued - but not totally surprised. The ability of LLMs to pass the "Winograd Schema Challenge" already showed that there is something going on. Example:

Human:
(1) The cat ate the mouse, it was tasty. Who was tasty: the cat or the mouse?
(2) The cat ate the mouse, it was hungry. Who was hungry: the cat or the mouse?

AI:
(1) The mouse was tasty.
(2) The cat was hungry.

... and you can easily try that for yourself.

That paper is here:
https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.02387

#SentientSyllabus #ChatGPT #HigherEd #AI #Education #TheoryOfMind #Mind #Intelligence

title: A quick and sobering guide to cloning yourself

last_post.content:
Wharton professor Ethan Mollick has an interesting piece on how easy it was for him to create an entirely-synthetic video of him lecturing, using AI text, voice, and video generation tools.

https://oneusefulthing.substack.com/p/a-quick-and-sobering-guide-to-cloning?utm_source=direct&r=i5f7&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web

Ok so. In light of much talking about Bing, Bard and "truth", I looked at what the "Stochastic 🦜" paper warned. The first 2 things, "automatically write term papers" and "interact on social media" have already come true. So....now do we just wait for the third to happen?

Plug for our event! With @emilymbender and @timnitGebru https://www.eventbrite.com/e/stochastic-parrots-day-tickets-524219965027

Energy (Northern CA)
PGE offers a 20% discount on gas and electricity bills if you have low income - for a single person that is $36,000 or less
https://www.pge.com/en_US/residential/save-energy-money/help-paying-your-bill/longer-term-assistance/care/care.page?

• 3 people: $46,060/year

3rd #fanzine project we provide scans to is the #InternetArchive Fanfiction Fanzine Collection

Also done with publisher permission. In fact some publishers have had these zines up on their websites for a decade (or longer) and we're helping them move to the Internet Archive as they wind down their websites

https://archive.org/details/fanzines-collection

4/n

2nd #fanzine #preservation
#project - we provide scans to
Texas A&M University digital fanzine archive.

This was named after my friend Sandy Hereld and launched in 2013. It is a closed archive, meaning you have to be onsite to see the scans or #TAMU faculty or staff. Publishers have given permission for some of the scans to be available publicly online. Contributors to the zines can always opt out.

https://oaktrust.library.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/149935

and

https://fanlore.org/wiki/Sandy_Hereld_Memorial_Digitized_Media_Fanzine_Collection

As an exercise in minimalism, I stripped my blogging template down to a bare-bones repo, generating a static-site blog with RSS that publishes to github pages (or wherever) using pandoc and svelte-kit. Audience is maybe beginners, people who love pandoc and are thinking of moving on from Jekyll/Hugo, or people just curious to see how a svelte-kit site works. The whole filesystem-based router has been really eye-opening for me, personally. https://bmschmidt.github.io/bare-bones-blog/ https://github.com/bmschmidt/bare-bones-blog

Super proud/excited to share our paper "Pygmalion Displacement: When Humanising AI Dehumanises Women" wherein we develop a lens to help us trace a type of harm towards women within/by AI as a field & as a technology: https://osf.io/preprints/socarxiv/jqxb6

1/4

Physicist John Tyndall is often credited with discovering the greenhouse effect, which he wrote about in 1859.

But female scientist Eunice Foote published a paper - 3 years earlier - demonstrating how atmospheric water vapor & CO2 affected solar heating. She theorized that heat trapping gases in Earth’s atmosphere warm its #climate.

Tyndall was widely read. And Foote, being a woman, wasn't even permitted to present her own work. https://www.climate.gov/news-features/features/happy-200th-birthday-eunice-foote-hidden-climate-science-pioneer #history #science #ClimateChange

@allisonwkoh There’s the [@citation] syntax you can use to cite sources from a bibliography file: https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/footnotes-and-citations.html

The best way to go about this workflow, imo, is to use Zotero and {rbbt}. I wrote a little about how to do this here: https://tidytales.ca/series/2023-01-24_reproducible-data-science/posts/zotero-setup.html#using-zotero-for-citations-in-quarto-and-r-markdown-documents
